Ordered mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spinel catalysts with high catalytic performance for methane combustion Tae Hwan Lim a Su Bin Park b Ji Man Kim b Do Heui Kim a ⁎ a School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Institute of Chemical Processes, Seoul National University, 1 Gwanak-ro, Gwanak-gu, Seoul 151-742, Republic of Korea School of Chemical and Biological Engineering Institute of Chemical Processes Seoul National University 1 Gwanak-ro Gwanak-gu Seoul 151-742 Republic of Korea b Department of Chemistry, Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU), Suwon, Gyeonggi-do 440-746, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU) Suwon Gyeonggi-do 440-746 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ordered mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spinel catalysts were synthesized via nano-replication method using mesoporous silica KIT-6 as the hard template. They were applied to methane combustion, in comparison with bulk MCo2O4 spinel catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method. A combined N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD and TEM results clearly confirm that mesoporous MCo2O4 (m-MCo2O4) spinel catalysts contain ordered mesostructure, resulting in the higher BET surface area and pore volume than bulk ones (b-MCo2O4). Moreover, the former catalysts demonstrate the better thermal stability as indicated by larger amount of MCo2O4 phase and smaller size of crystallite domain after calcination at 550°C. Therefore, such excellent properties rationalize that the m-MCo2O4 spinel catalysts reveal higher catalytic activity for methane combustion than bulk counterparts. When it comes to the catalytic performance of the meso catalysts for methane combustion, the m-CuCo2O4 spinel catalyst has superior performance, which is related to the high normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface, as evidenced by XPS. Keywords Methane combustion Metal cobalt spinel Mesoporous mixed metal oxide 1 Introduction Methane, as the most abundant hydrocarbon source, can be applied to replace the petroleum-based fuel for transportation. Natural gas vehicles (NGVs) have been receiving considerable attention as an effective way to reduce the emission of nitrogen oxides, hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide in comparison with gasoline- and diesel-powered vehicles; therefore, they become popular for urban transportation [1,2]. However, the global warming potential of unburned methane emitted from NGVs is 21times higher than that of carbon dioxide so that unburned methane is considered as a potent greenhouse gas [3,4]. Thus, it is expected to regulate the emission of methane not only from NGVs but also from on-road engines and, consequently, the emission of unburned methane must be reduced significantly. Catalytic combustion of methane (CCM) has drawn considerable attention by using various transition metal oxides (e.g., Mn, Fe, Cu, Co, Ni, Cu, etc.) [5–12]. Among these transition metal oxides, metal cobalt spinel oxides (MCo2O4; M=Cu, Ni, Zn, etc.) are known to be prepared by substituting cobalt metal in spinel structure with various 3d transition metals, and they have special electric, magnetic and catalytic properties for the various industrial fields [13–15]. Our previous study reported that CoNi (50:50) and (67:33) samples having distorted NiCo2O4 spinel structure exhibit the larger portion of surface oxygen species and the enhanced reducibility, thus leading to the superior catalytic performance for methane combustion in comparison with Co3O4 [16]. Zhu et al. reported the promotional effect of mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Mn and Ni) spinels on CO oxidation and, especially, the high activity and robust stability of mesoporous CuCo2O4 and MnCo2O4 catalyst [17]. Tan et al. claimed that ZnCo2O4 exhibits the highest oxygen evolution performance due to the large amount of the surface Co cations [18]. However, many previous studies reported that single metal oxide phase is formed from the thermal decomposition of MCo2O4 spinel phase above 400°C so that it requires the improved thermal stability [19–21]. Recently, mesoporous metal oxides have been widely studied for many catalytic applications. They are synthesized via nano-replication method using mesoporous silica as a template, resulting in well-defined mesopore, high surface area and small crystallite domain size [22,23]. Wang et al. claimed that mesoporous 3 dimensional (3D) Co3O4 has the superior performance of formaldehyde oxidation than nano and 2 dimensional (2D) Co3O4 because of its excellent characteristics such as 3D porous channel structure, high specific surface area and abundant active surface oxygen species [24]. Cabo et al. reported that mesoporous NiCo2O4 sample has NiCo2O4 phase content of about 97wt% after calcination at 550°C, confirming the improved thermal stability of NiCo2O4 spinel phase [14]. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no previous research about the application of mesoporous metal cobalt spinel oxides to catalytic combustion of methane. In the present study, ordered mesoporous MCo2O4 spinel catalysts were synthesized via nano-replication method using cubic Ia3d mesoporous silica KIT-6 as the hard template and bulk MCo2O4 spinel catalysts were prepared by conventional co-precipitation method, both of which were applied to methane combustion reaction. N2 adsorption-desorption, ICP-AES, TEM, XRD, XPS and EXAFS were utilized to investigate textural and structural property of all MCo2O4 spinel catalysts. Therefore, we aimed at comparing catalytic properties of mesoporous MCo2O4 spinel catalysts with bulk ones and finding the optimized MCo2O4 spinel catalyst having superior catalytic performance for methane combustion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of KIT-6 KIT-6, which is well known as mesoporous silica with cubic Ia3d symmetry, was prepared using well-established synthesis procedure [25]. In a typical process, P123 was dissolved in a mixed solution of distilled water, 1-butanol and concentrated HCl while stirring at 35°C. After 1h, TEOS was dropped into the solution while stirring at 35°C. The mixture was stirred at 35°C for 24h, followed by hydrothermal aging at 100°C for 24h in a closed polypropylene bottle. The resulting solid product was filtered and dried at 80°C overnight. For removal of surfactant, the as-synthesized silica KIT-6 powders were treated with an ethanol-HCl mixture while stirring for 3h, and subsequently calcined at 550°C for 3h. 2.1.2 Synthesis of MCo2O4 spinel catalysts The several mesoporous MCo2O4 spinel catalysts such as mesoporous CuCo2O4, ZnCo2O4 and NiCo2O4 were synthesized via nano-replication method [22]. In the typical preparation of mesoporous CuCo2O4 spinel, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O with the molar ratio of 1:2 were dissolved in ethanol, and the solution was impregnated into the pores of KIT-6. Subsequently, the impregnated KIT-6 was dried at 80°C overnight, and calcined at 550°C for 3h. The silica template was removed by treating the composite with 2M NaOH solution two times. Finally, the template-free mesoporous MCo2O4 spinel was collected by filtration and washed with distilled water several times, followed by drying at 80°C overnight. Mesoporous ZnCo2O4 and NiCo2O4 spinel were synthesized in a similar way using Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O as precursor of zinc and nickel, respectively. Mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spinel catalysts were designated as m-MCo2O4 in this manuscript. Bulk MCo2O4 spinel catalysts such as bulk CuCo2O4, ZnCo2O4 and NiCo2O4 were prepared by co-precipitation method and designated as b-MCo2O4 in this manuscript [16]. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), Optima-4300 DV (PerkinElmer), was used to obtain an actual atomic M/Co (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) ratio for each sample. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using an ASAP 2010 (Micromeritics) at −195.7°C. Prior to the measurement, all samples were degassed under evacuated condition at 250°C for at least 6h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method were applied to estimate the BET surface area and pore size distributions, respectively. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns corresponding to low angle and wide angle region were recorded using Cu-Kα radiation at 30kV and 40mA on the Rigaku D/MAX-III and Rigaku Smart Lab, respectively. The crystal structure parameters were determined using the materials analysis using diffraction (MAUD) Rietveld refinement program [26]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEM-2100F (JEOL) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The solution, prepared by dispersing small amount of samples in ethanol, was dropped on a carbon-coated Cu grid and dried at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted in a VG Multilab 2000 spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corporation) with a Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV), and the spectra were calibrated using the carbon C 1s at 284.6eV for standard. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were obtained using synchrotron radiation at the beam line 7D in Pohang Light Source (PLS). The obtained data were analyzed with ATHENA following the process in the literature [27]. 2.3 Methane combustion reaction The methane combustion was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor. The catalysts were mixed with α-Al2O3 bead to dissipate the heat caused by the reaction. The reactants was composed of 1500ppm CH4, 12.12 vol% O2 and balancing N2 with a total flow rate 200ml/min and supplied to the catalysts bed via mass flow controllers (MKS) at a space velocity of 60,000mlgcat −1 h−1. Activity data were obtained after stabilizing at each temperature for 40min. The reactants and products were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (Agilent 6890N) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a packed column (Supelco 12390-U). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 ICP-AES and N2 adsorption-desorption An actual atomic M/Co (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) ratio of all MCo2O4 spinel samples was examined using ICP-AES. As indicated in Table 1 , the ICP-AES results clearly exhibit that the actual composition of all the samples is well matched with that of nominal loading. In order to verify the mesoporosity, m-MCo2O4 spinel samples were investigated with N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. As displayed in Fig. 1 , all the meso samples show a type IV isotherm with H1 hysteresis loop and a narrow pore size distribution located at about 3.2nm, confirming the formation of mesostructure [22]. There is a broad pore size distribution centered at about 17nm, which may be caused by the filling of only one set of pores in KIT-6, as claimed by Jiao et al. [28]. The BET surface area and pore volume of all MCo2O4 spinel samples are also summarized in Table 1. Bulk MCo2O4 spinel samples have low BET surface area (20–35m2/g) and small pore volume (0.09–0.15cm3/g). Previous reports about various MCo2O4 spinels have shown low BET surface area and small pore volume. For example, CuCo2O4 spinel catalysts synthesized via thermal decomposition method, co-precipitation method and solution combustion synthesis method have BET surface area of 4.8, 22.6 and 3.6m2/g after calcination at 500–600°C, respectively [29–31]. It is caused by the weak thermal stability of MCo2O4 spinel above 400°C, which can lead to the sintering of crystalline simultaneously with a severe loss in BET surface area. In contrast, m-MCo2O4 spinel samples prepared by nano-replication method show high BET surface area (89–113m2/g) and large pore volume (0.29–0.34cm3/g) after calcination at 550°C. Such values are higher than those of the bulk samples and similar to the previous samples prepared by using nano-replication method [32–34]. Therefore, it can be claimed that nano-replication method is very effective for the synthesis of metal cobalt spinel catalysts having superior thermal stability after calcination up to 550°C. 3.2 TEM TEM analysis was also performed to confirm the mesoporosity of m-MCo2O4 spinel samples. As shown in Fig. 2 (a)–(c), TEM images show that the wall thickness of the meso metal cobalt spinel oxide (about 7.0nm) is well matched with the pore size diameter (about 6.8nm) of KIT-6 template (Fig. 1(a)) [35]. It suggests that m-MCo2O4 spinel samples are well replicated from the KIT-6 template, which is in agreement with previous studies about hard templating method using mesoporous silica KIT-6 [36]. Consequently, TEM images obviously prove the formation of well-dispersed MCo2O4 spinel into the pore channels of the KIT-6 with the ordered hexagonal mesostructure in the meso sample, which can be related to the excellent textural property. 3.3 XRD Low angle XRD analysis was carried out to check the mesoporous structure of KIT-6 and m-MCo2O4 spinel samples. As presented in Fig. 3 (a) and (b), the low angle XRD patterns for KIT-6 show a main peak at around 1.1° and two shoulder peaks at around 1.3° and 1.9° respectively, which is characteristics of cubic Ia3d symmetry [25]. The low angle XRD patterns for the meso samples display (110) and (211) reflection of at around 0.6° and 1.1°, respectively. The presence of (211) reflection underlines the formation of ordered mesostructure and the appearance of (110) reflection signifies phase transition from the cubic Ia3d symmetry to the tetragonal I41/a symmetry after removal of the silica template [37]. Consequently, the low angle XRD patterns demonstrate the formation of ordered mesoporous structures of the meso samples, corresponding to the results of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and TEM analysis. The crystal structure of all MCo2O4 spinel samples was examined by wide angle XRD analysis. As displayed in Fig. 3(c), all peaks for the wide angle XRD patterns of the samples are assigned to cubic MCo2O4 spinel phase with the space group of Fd3m [227] such as Cu0.92Co2.08O4 (JCPDS 01-076-1887), ZnCo2O4 (JCPDS 00-001-1149) and NiCo2O4 (JCPDS 01-073-1702) and single metal oxide phase such as CuO (JCPDS 00-001-1117), ZnO (JCPDS 00-001-1136) and NiO (JCPDS 00-001-1239). Here, it is observed that although all the samples have a similar spinel structure, their lattice parameter for MCo2O4 spinel phase is slightly different due to the substitution of several metals for cobalt in spinel structure, as evidenced by the lattice parameter of MCo2O4 phase in Table 2 . The lattice parameter, phase amount and crystallite domain size were estimated from the MAUD Rietveld refinement for the wide angle XRD patterns, as listed in Table 2. The value of phase amount is quantitatively calculated using relative peak intensity ratio [14]. As presented in Table 2, m-MCo2O4 spinel samples exhibit not only the larger amount of MCo2O4 phase but also the smaller size of crystallite domain than those of b-MCo2O4 spinel samples, which implies that the meso samples are more resistant to the decomposition of MCo2O4 phase and the sintering of crystallite domain during calcination process at 550°C so that they are more thermally stable than the bulk samples. The enhancement of thermal stability can be related to well-dispersed MCo2O4 spinel phase into the pore channels of KIT-6, as displayed in TEM images. Consequently, the combined N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD and TEM results of the meso samples can unambiguously account for the excellent textural property such as high BET surface area, the large amount of MCo2O4 phase and the smaller size of crystallite domain. 3.4 XPS XPS analysis was used to analyze the surface composition and oxidation state of cobalt. In Fig. 4 , Co 2p photoelectron spectra for m-MCo2O4 spinel samples display two main peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 corresponding to binding energy at 779.6 and 794.9eV, respectively. Co 2p3/2 spectra are de-convoluted into two spin-orbit doublets of Co3+ and Co2+ cations with binding energy at about 779.1 and 780.6eV, respectively [24]. Surface atomic composition, Co3+/Cototal ratio and normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface are presented in Table 3 . The ratios of Co3+/Cototal demonstrate the decrease in the following order: m-ZnCo2O4 >m-CuCo2O4 >m-NiCo2O4. According to this result, m-ZnCo2O4 has the highest Co3+/Cototal ratio, while m-NiCo2O4 has the lowest Co3+/Cototal ratio among the meso catalysts and, therefore, cobalt oxidation state are influenced by substitution of metal. We obtained the normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface by multiplying the Co3+/Cototal ratio by the atomic percent of cobalt on the surface. As presented in Table 3, the normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface decreases as follows: m-CuCo2O4 >m-ZnCo2O4 >m-NiCo2O4, which is different from that of Co3+/Cototal ratio. It is worth noting that m-CuCo2O4 catalyst has the highest normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface among the meso catalysts. Such high quantity of Co3+ cations may be expected to have a strong impact on oxidation because Co3+ cations could be easily reduced in the temperature range where methane combustion occurs [9,38]. 3.5 EXAFS EXAFS analysis of Co K-edge and M K-edge (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) was applied to examine information about the location of substituted atoms. As shown in Fig. 5 , the Co K-edge and M K-edge (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) EXAFS spectra exhibit three main peaks below 4Å. Note that real atomic bond distance is obtained by adding a typical value of 0.3–0.4Å to the radial distance because the phase shift for radial distance is not corrected. In Fig. 5(a), three peaks of Co K-edge spectra for standard Co3O4 sample at about 1.52Å, 2.47Å and 2.97Å are assigned to the atomic distance of Co–O, octahedral Co–octahedral Co (Cooct–Cooct) and octahedral Co–tetrahedral Co (Cooct–Cotet), respectively [39]. Similarly, three peaks of M K-edge (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spectra for m-MCo2O4 spinel catalysts at about 1.54Å, 2.52Å and 2.98Å confirm the atomic distance of M–O, Moct–Moct and Moct–Mtet, respectively, as displayed in Fig. 5(b)–(d). The Cu K-edge spectra clearly show three main peaks for Cu–O, Cuoct–Cuoct and Cuoct–Cutet. The Zn K-edge spectra evidently indicate two main peaks for Zn–O and Znoct–Zntet, and a shoulder peak for Znoct-Znoct. The Ni K-edge spectra clearly exhibit two main peaks for Ni–O and Nioct–Nioct, and a shoulder peak for Nioct–Nitet. Thus, such results obviously suggest that Cu atoms occupy both tetrahedral and octahedral sites while Zn and Ni atoms mainly occupy tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the spinel structure, respectively [40]. Co3O4 has a normal spinel structure of AB2O4 type consisting of Co2+ cations in a tetrahedral coordination and Co3+ cations in an octahedral coordination. It could be expected that Co3+/Cototal ratio decreases when another metal cations occupy octahedral sites in the spinel structure, whereas Co3+/Cototal ratio increases when another metal cations occupy tetrahedral sites in the spinel structure. Both XPS and EXAFS results show the close relationship between cobalt oxidation state and location of substituted metal atoms in the all meso samples. The m-CuCo2O4, where Cu atoms occupy both tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the spinel structure, is used as a criterion to compare with the other meso samples. Zn atoms mainly occupy tetrahedral sites in the spinel structure and the Co3+/Cototal ratio of m-ZnCo2O4 is higher than that of m-CuCo2O4. It means that Zn2+ cations are substituted with Co2+ cations in a tetrahedral site [41]. On the other hand, Ni atoms mainly occupy octahedral sites in the spinel structure and the Co3+/Cototal ratio of m-NiCo2O4 is lower than that of m-CuCo2O4. It means that Ni2+ and Ni3+ cations are substituted with Co3+ cations in an octahedral site [42,43]. 3.6 Methane combustion activity Catalytic methane combustion was performed to evaluate the catalytic performance of all MCo2O4 spinel catalysts, as shown in the light-off curves of Fig. 6 . T50 and T90, at which the methane conversion reaches 50% and 90%, respectively, are considered as the criterion of the catalytic activity for methane combustion. As listed in Table 1, the T50 and T90 of m-CuCo2O4 are 369 and 440°C, both of which are 50 and 89°C lower than those of b-CuCo2O4, respectively. The T50 and T90 of m-ZnCo2O4 are 373 and 450°C, both of which are 60 and 101°C lower than those of b-ZnCo2O4, respectively. The T50 and T90 of m-NiCo2O4 are 382 and 458°C, both of which are 13 and 29°C lower than those of b-NiCo2O4, respectively. Consequently, the T50 and T90 of the meso catalysts are markedly lower than those of the bulk catalysts. A combined N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD and TEM results clearly demonstrate that m-MCo2O4 spinel catalysts have unique structure like ordered mesostructure and excellent thermal stability at 550°C, leading to improvement of catalytic activity for methane combustion in comparison with b-MCo2O4. Interestingly, activity of m-NiCo2O4 is lower than that of m-CuCo2O4 and m-ZnCo2O4, although b-NiCo2O4 exhibits superior activity among the bulk catalysts. According to the N2 adsorption-desorption and XRD results, Ni metal substituted Co3O4 (b-NiCo2O4) exhibits the smaller size of crystallite domain and higher surface area than the Cu and Zn metal substituted Co3O4 (b-CuCo2O4 and b-ZnCo2O4) after calcination at 550°C, which confirms the enhanced thermal stability. In case of synthesized catalysts via nano-replication method, however, improvements by substitution of nickel for cobalt in spinel structure are lower than those of the other metals. In comparison with methane combustion activity of the meso catalysts, the descending order of activity is as follows: m-CuCo2O4 >m-ZnCo2O4 >m-NiCo2O4. Especially, m-CuCo2O4 show the highest activity among all the catalysts. According to XPS, tendency of activity is almost the same to that of the normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface and, especially, m-CuCo2O4 spinel catalyst exhibits the highest normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface among the meso catalysts. Thus, methane combustion activity increases with increasing normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface and, therefore, it can be summarized that the high normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface can account for the improvement of activity. 4 Conclusions Ordered mesoporous and bulk MCo2O4 spinel catalysts were successfully synthesized via nano-replication method using mesoporous silica KIT-6 as the hard template and co-precipitation method, respectively. As synthesized catalysts were examined by methane combustion reaction test and various characterizations such as N2 adsorption-desorption, ICP-AES, TEM, XRD, XPS and EXAFS. A combined N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD and TEM results evidently verify that m-MCo2O4 spinel catalysts have ordered mesostructure and thermal stability at 550°C, leading to improvement of catalytic activity for methane combustion in comparison with b-MCo2O4. According to activity and characterization results, the m-CuCo2O4 spinel catalyst has superior performance, which is attributed to the high normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface. coredata.dc:description: Ordered mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spinel catalysts were synthesized via nano-replication method using mesoporous silica KIT-6 as the hard template. They were applied to methane combustion, in comparison with bulk MCo2O4 spinel catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method. A combined N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD and TEM results clearly confirm that mesoporous MCo2O4 (m-MCo2O4) spinel catalysts contain ordered mesostructure, resulting in the higher BET surface area and pore volume than bulk ones (b-MCo2O4). Moreover, the former catalysts demonstrate the better thermal stability as indicated by larger amount of MCo2O4 phase and smaller size of crystallite domain after calcination at 550°C. Therefore, such excellent properties rationalize that the m-MCo2O4 spinel catalysts reveal higher catalytic activity for methane combustion than bulk counterparts. When it comes to the catalytic performance of the meso catalysts for methane combustion, the m-CuCo2O4 spinel catalyst has superior performance, which is related to the high normalized amount of Co3+ cations on the surface, as evidenced by XPS.
coredata.dc:title: Ordered mesoporous MCo2O4 (M=Cu, Zn and Ni) spinel catalysts with high catalytic performance for methane combustion
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
